Award.AwardTitle: EarSketch: An Authentic, Studio-Based STEAM Approach to High School Computing Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the influence on positive student achievement and engagement (particularly among populations traditionally under-represented in computer science) of an intervention that integrates a computational music remixing tool -EarSketch- with the Computer Science Principles, a view of computing literacy that is emerging as a new standard for Advanced Placement and other high school computer science courses. The project is grounded on the premise that EarSketch, a STEM + Art (STEAM) learning environment, embodies authenticity (i.e., its cultural and industry relevance in both arts and STEM domains), along with a context that facilitates communication and collaboration among students (i.e., through a studio-based learning approach). These elements are critical to achieving successful outcomes across diverse student populations. Using agent-based modeling, the research team will investigate what factors enhance or impede implementation of authentic STEAM tools in different school settings.

The researchers will be engaged in a multi-stage process to develop: a) an implementation-ready, web-based EarSketch learning environment that integrates programming, digital audio workstation, curriculum, audio loop library, and social sharing features, along with studio-based learning functionality to support student presentation, critique, discussion, and collaboration; and b) an online professional learning course for teachers adopting EarSketch in Computer Science Principles courses. Using these resources, the team will conduct a quasi-experimental study of EarSketch in Computer Science Principles high school courses across the state of Georgia; measure student learning and engagement across multiple demographic categories; and determine to what extent an EarSketch-based CS Principles course promotes student achievement and engagement across different student populations. The project will include measures of student performance, creativity, collaboration, and communication in student programming tasks to determine the extent to which studio-based learning in EarSketch promotes success in these important areas. An agent-based modeling framework in multiple school settings will be developed to determine what factors enhance or impede implementation of EarSketch under conditions of routine practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project team designed, developed, and deployed a newly-designed, web-based, free implementation of the EarSketch learning environment. EarSketch is designed to engage diverse high school student populations in computer science by teaching CS in the context of music production and remixing. The environment includes student and teacher-facing curriculum materials aligned with the Computer Science Principles course; a library of ~4000 sounds that serve as the building blocks for student remixes; sharing and collaboration features; and a digital audio workstation interface. The team also developed a series of professional development offerings to help teachers adopt EarSketch in their classrooms.

A series of research studies across multiple schools in five school districts explored the relationship between the perceived authenticity of the platform by students, classroom implementation factors, changes in student attitudes, and student growth in content knowledge and in intention to persist in the field of computing. Examples of findings from these studies are that students' interest in sharing the music they create with EarSketch outside of the classroom most predicts increased intention to persist in computing; and that classroom implementation factors correlate with students' intentions to persist in computing much more so than with their attitudes toward computing or content knowledge acquisition. Findings such as these may more broadly inform the design of creative computing environments for education and the design of professional development activities for teachers.

The team also conducted a meta-analysis across several years of studies with EarSketch to better understand students' intention to persist in computing. Findings included that students significantly increased their intentions to persist in computing across the studies and that these increases were predicted by student attitudes towards computing and the perceived authenticity of the EarSketch environment.

The team also investigated the combination of theories of change, a traditional method used to guide methodology and evaluation of educational interventions, with causal loop diagrams, a technique adopted from complex systems modeling to visualize the complex relationships and feedback loops among the many attributes affecting the implementation and sustainability of an intervention within a complex educational ecosystem. Together, these two techniques can help a research team to iteratively assess and improve the intervention it is creating, refine its theories around its impact on students, and communicate these ideas to a broad audience of researchers, administrators, and teachers.

Beyond its use in research studies, the EarSketch software and learning environment is in widespread use in education. Over the five years of this project, EarSketch has been used by over 380,000 unique users from all 50 states and 150 countries. It has been recognized with an Engagement Excellence Award from the National Center for Women and Information Technology (2017), an American Association of School Librarians Best Website for Teaching & Learning (2018), and has been featured at demonstrations, workshops, and related events at numerous local, regional, and national conferences both for researchers and practitioners. Free teacher materials and access to the free online professional development have been requested by 784 teachers to date. The team has also published and presented peer-reviewed articles summarizing research findings in a variety of high-impact venues for computer science education, STEM education, music technology education, education evaluation, systems modeling, and education technology.
